title.narrative: Partnership Coordination And The New Urban Agenda

description.narrative:
Given the current global attention on the New Urban Agenda and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Urban Development, it is important for all relevant stakeholders, state and non-state, to trust each other and work together in advancing sustainable human settlements and urban development. The PCNUA project aims to increase the engagement of all stakeholders of human settlements and urban development, including people in vulnerable situations, in the design and implementation of national and regional policies and programmes on human settlements and urban development.
The second phase of the PCNUA project proposes to build in established partnerships and progress made in the first phase of the project to enhance the success of multisectoral partnerships by ensuring that all stakeholders take part in ongoing processes at all levels. Project implementation will entail (a) support to the participation of all stakeholders at regional and global platforms, and to their engagement with governments and intergovernmental institutions at national, regional and global milestones including the Asia Pacific Urban Forum, implementation of the New Urban Agenda and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, (b) raise awareness and share information with both state and non-state actors on the importance of inclusivity and participatory approach in the attainment of sustainability in human settlements and urban development, (c) sensitize and mobilize Partners for engagement in processes related to sustainable urban development in the Asia Pacific region while building their capacity to effectively advocate for adequate policy tools, legislation and frameworks that will help ease the pressure by challenges of urbanization, (d) strengthen state and non-state partner relations as well as with other UN agencies and development partners, and (e) provide networking opportunities among different stakeholders of human settlements and urban development in the Asia Pacific region.
The project’s target beneficiaries, stakeholders of human settlements and urban development and selected officers of cities, national and local governments will benefit directly by participating in all planned activities. They will contribute directly to debates, discussions and capacity building initiatives and by sharing outcomes of these activities with their respective networks. They will benefit from the networking and exchanges of experiences, all backstopped by UN-Habitat expertise at the headquarters and at regional level. They will expand their networks, strengthen their voice at regional and global political processes, and be equipped with knowledge of current challenges of urbanization and what their roles are in addressing them. They will in turn be more effective actors at their neighborhood, and influence policies at the local and national levels in partnership with their municipalities and national governments.
From partners feedback received during the project’s first phase, most of the non-state stakeholders are disjointed and dissatisfied with government led policy and programmes development and implementation processes. The project provides an opportunity for partners from the region to share the same platform with their respective governments for joint discussions and debates aimed at strengthening their relations. The project further compliments the agency’s External Relations Division in its efforts to streamline UN-Habitat’s engagement with respective stakeholders especially in positioning itself as the lead agency in issues related to sustainable human settlements an urban development.
The project partners include all UN-Habitat Branches, offices and liaison offices, ACHR, UCLG ASPAC, Kemitraan Habitat, all human settlements and urban development stakeholders, ASEAN, SAARC, private sector operators and national governments. Through PCNUA, UN-Habitat will be providing knowledge services, advisory services as well as support skills through consultations, network management, capacity building, and reporting.
